title: What will be the US civilian unemployment rate (U3) for August 2021?
preds: The numbers will be released on friday. Latest sum of 51 estimates on Bloomberg is 5,2% with a standard deviation of 0,08%.  I stick with my 88/12.
It's 50/50, standing on 5.4%. Some states have extreme unemployment rates, while some states have low unemployment rates.
Switching to favor below 5.4% based on the consensus forecast others have linked.
Consensus coming in at 5.2%. Consistent with strengthening labor market and relatively low claims.  https://m.investing.com/economic-calendar/unemployment-rate-300

https://www.forecasts.org/unemploy.htm U.S. Unemployment Rate Forecast U.S. Unemployment Rate Forecast Values Percent Unemployed, Seasonally Adjusted. Month	Date	Forecast Value	Avg Error
0	Jul 2021	5.4	±0.0
1	Aug 2021	5.2	±0.08

Falling initial claims, tight labor market, and not much actual shutting down in the US. I can't find a lot of reputable forecasts yet, but this one has the August rate coming in at 5.2%: https://www.forecasts.org/unemploy.htm

The July data was strong, and the level is now 5,4%, momentum in the economy is also strong, employers like Amazon and McDonalds are raising their wages and the covid incentives not to take a job has been or will be removed in these months. Im sure there will be created 800.000-1.000.000 new jobs in august as well, which should make the number go under 5,4%. The biggest unsertanty is the way the unemployment number is calculated. The improved labor enviroment will incurage more people to look for a job which will make the denominator increase as the "labor force participation rate" increases.

It is 5.4% i  July,
 I estimate any change (incrase in unemployment rate to be within 2%.
Not sure why the crowd is so confident in it staying the same or higher but I'll hedge toward the crowd a bit and favor bucket two.
Many people going on vacation and many people to be hired seasonal. I see “hiring now” boards in many places, this should push down the rate.
It's just dropped to 5.4%, so, yeah, I was too pessimistic in my previous forecasts.

Larger than expected drop in unemployment rate for July. Down to 5.4% already. But possible COVID surges make a dent in this momentum for August. Higher than expected unemployment claims this week.
Still leaning to the 5.4 to 5.9 bucket for now.

Rethinking this a little bit. First, I'm getting rid of the higher categories as surveyors are currently in the field collecting August numbers (so lockdown risk is abated). I'm also inclined to believe that the drop in July has a lot to do with unemployed persons with no intention of finding work falling off the rolls. My intuition says that we will see more reentrants in the numbers for August, thus pushing the number up slightly (I'm thinking 5.6%).

This whole thread is particularly useful, but this tweet breaks down some of the monthly increases and decreases in unemployment we've seen by category which is interesting. Not sure what to do on this yet, but switching to favor below 5.4% by a little bit now: https://twitter.com/bencasselman/status/1423636419696803841

Wow, big drop to 5.4% in July. That leaves August pretty questionable and I'm kicking myself for switching to heavily favor the second bucket recently. I wonder if we're seeing the effects of half of the states ending enhanced unemployment insurance, which according to the dates listed here looks like a lot of that effect would kick in around July. [1] In recent months the unemployment rate has followed a bit of a zigzag, dropping one month, increasing a bit the next, kind of a 2 steps down 1 step up pattern. I wonder if we'll see that happen here and it will stick at 5.4% or above for August. That's what I'm leaning toward right now, but I might change my mind later after considering whether UI ending in the listed states will result in a steadier downward trend. [1] https://time.com/nextadvisor/in-the-news/25-states-ending-unemployment-benefits-early/

Uptick in initial jobless claims, even though existing claims are shrinking.
Worker’s re-entering the labor force will slow downward momentum.

I have been too stubborn in changing my mind on this question. The gap lower that I was expecting looks like it may only happen in Sept/Oct when some of the unemployment benefits roll off, and schools reopen to mitigate childcare requirements.

Yeah, this is not the sort of thing that indicates strong reopening rehiring underway: "Jobless claims unexpectedly rose to 419,000 last week, higher than the 350,000 Dow Jones estimate and more than the upwardly revised 368,000 from the previous period, the Labor Department reported Thursday." https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/21/stock-market-futures-open-to-close-news.html

In 880 overlapping samples of 2 month changes, only 45 times have you had a move of 0.5% or more downward. That's a 5% probability, which I'm doubling because of the directional catalyst of re-opening.
The crowd may be underestimating the chance of a reversal here. I'm adjusting in the pessimistic direction while watching for July numbers and how the President responds to the growing virus spread.
The current (July 2021) National Unemployment rate nationally is around 6%.
I adjust my low end up, as I understand that the extraordinary covid unemployment benefits in some states first will be abandoned in september.

Labor force participation is increasing in the short term but not dramatically. More people are finding jobs but not dramatically. I do not see any factors that would lead me to conclude the unemployment report would shock.
Many states are cutting unemployment benefits: https://www.businessinsider.com/republican-states-cutting-unemployment-benefits-expanded-300-weekly-biden-stimulus-2021-5#maryland-11

The trend is clearly down, the economy i strong, it will not turn in two months, so the risk to the main scenario is if removement of unemployment benefits will make unemployed to move back in an fill maybe 2 mill. jobs in two month getting it back to pre-covid levels (see link below). If so unemployment will drop below 5,4%. https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/job-offers

There is great confidence in a recovery , covid vaccination has been fast and succesful...
but statistical unemployment rate requires time to proceed with pre-covid levels "
"Unfortunately, I think it will take the country quite a while to get back to the pre-crisis levels. There are a couple of reasons for this," Quinnipiac University associate professor of management Tuvana Rua said in a statement. "The first one is the fact that the country was at an all time low in terms of unemployment levels, which did not happen over night. Prior to reaching the all time low of 3.6% unemployment rate in January 2020, the civilian unemployment rate had been trending down since November 2009." She continued: "If we were to compare what we are facing now as an economic crisis with the most recent financial crisis of 2008, we will see that it took us 10 years to return to pre-2008 financial crisis civilian unemployment rate of 4.7%. So that is some historical data that we can use as a reference."

Unemployment rate ticked up from 5.8 to 5.9% in June. I don't think it will continue to tick up, as states remove unemployment benefits and ease Covid restrictions, but I do think that 5.4% is too extreme a fall for it to go to in 2 months.

My first linear guess was that less than 5.4% was very unlikely and that the most likely was the 5.4-5.9% range and more than 5.9% but apparently there's a lot of Labor force available that could become employed in the next few months. so I updated upwards on the less than 5.4% by 6%.

Like I said back when the May report came out, labor force participation rates were depressed, "so there's a lot of slack for new jobs to draw people back into participation, which keeps [U3] unemployment [rates] up."

updating in advance of June numbers

Back of the envelope, think the most likely 5.8 based on 2021's numbers being ~1.57x or 1.64x 2019's and say the recovery continues; 5.8 is 1.57x 2019's August number. That said, there's a lot of probability mass in <5.4% versus the 0.5% band between 5.4 and 5.9 so put a lot of weight there. Likewise for >7.1% if things go south. One question not examined: I expect this number is often revised. Would be good to know if it is typically revised up or down and how much.
i would like to see another month of data before significantly revising my forecast. we are at 5.8% now, 5.4 is absolutely within reach.
service industry will add a chunk of jobs.

The May number is out: 5.8%. https://www.morningstar.com/news/dow-jones/2021060410527/us-nonfarm-payrolls-up-559k-in-may-unemployment-rate-fell-to-58-5th-update  Note, labor force participation is 1.7 percentage points lower now than in February 2020, so there's a lot of slack for new jobs to draw people back into participation, which keeps unemployment up.

Adjusting to favor under 5.4% very slightly. An average of 0.1% a month would put it right at 5.5% in August. But my guess is the next few months will see better employment growth than the slow-ish start from the last two months.

I think there is a lot of uncertainty created because schools will not be back in session, and many of the more generous unemployment benefits in (population dense) Democratic states will affect the number of people that ACTIVELY seek work. I imagine the cessation of these benefits in red states will boost the 'actively seeking' numbers which might increase the U3 rate even though the trend in U3 is decreasing.

Some republican governors are eliminating the supplemental UI in response to a belief that the more generous benefits are keeping people out of the workforce. 18k loss in manufacturing jobs. https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/05/07/business/stock-market-today

Unemployment is currently at 6% as of April. Steady improvement in employment rate, dropping 0.15%/month on avg over last 6 months. Continuing this rate would put employment rate near 5.0%, well below the 5.4% target by September, though rate is likely to slow as we reach 'full employment'. JOLTS index suggests plenty of available jobs (near 5yr highs). Unemployment benefits are extended until September, meaning there will be a small increase in jobs after benefits expire but the timing is unlikely to impact the release in Sept numbers. This timing could cause the number of people searching for jobs to increase, artificially raising the unemployment rate. Currently 4M are not in the labor force due to Pandemic and declining, with a steady 2M marginally attached  and .5M discouraged - these numbers are probably not large enough to impact the employment rate denominator if conditions rapidly improved.  There is room to surprise on the upside, especially if more retail and services re-open. Retail sales have been strong, with inventories remaining low and strong demand throughout the supply chain, increasing demand for manufacturing and service workers. Restaurant walk-in and reservations have improved from -60% v 2019 to -30%, and are likely to continue to improve as weather warms and outdoor seating becomes more comfortable. Air travel bookings continue to improve slowly, suggesting demand for hotels is rebounding.  Downside risks are low, as risks of a virus surge decline with more vaccines delivered. Vaccine rollout has been strong in the US, with over 230M vaccines delivered thru April 26, with 95M (28% of pop) fully vaccinated and 140M partially vaccinated (42%). Availability of vaccine remains tight, but there may be headwinds on vaccine demand due to government distrust and skepticism. Unlikely to see surges of cases overwhelming current hospital capacity in the US. Public support for additional lockdown restrictions is unlikely, even if cases surge.
A lot depends on how quickly vaccinations proceed. The current rate has dropped below 3M/day which puts August 75% inoculation at risk.
Current 4/19/21 is 6%, trend has been down
Full employment is within grasp, and all economic indicators are positive . In the lack of any unexpected major development (which can’t be predicted) we are looking at a very low employment rate

The unemployment rate is downward trend since it has peaked in April of 2020. If one simply linearly projects the current trend into the rest of 2021 then one gets to unemployment rate of around 5%. The current Federal programs will help and support this trend. However I think the pace of the decline in the unemployment rate will slow down as the labour participation rates will go up as the US economy improves. For instance, under normal economic conditions it took the US economy 12 months between September 2014 and 2015 to get from 6% to 5% unemployment rate and then for further 12 months or so it stayed around 5% before resuming the decrease towards 4%.

As of 3/8/21, rate is approx 6.8 (official). But, as we know, if people are not searching for a job, then they are not counted in the official statistics. So, if economy starts to improve, if significantly more people are vaccinated, then we could see more people try to enter the economy. This may actually keep the unemployment number higher (sticky) since economy will have to accommodate more searchers.
I believe if President Biden's stimulus package is approved, which seems very likely, then demand in the economy is going to soar leading to rising employment.

Historical annual declines while experiencing strong gdp growth is in range of 0.7-1.0% broadly speaking.  This implies range of 5.4-5.9 seems most reasonable.  4. Viewed very low possibility of sub 5.4%, seems implausible as many jobs will still not be around as economy transitions re covid.  5. Viewed nil probability of higher 5.9% plus, as USA will be fully vaccinated by May (at least one shot).

Even so, over 100,000 businesses have permanently shut down [1]. With still-limited capital, it is unlikely that the few remaining corporations can absorb the masses of unemployed workers. As a consequence, I'd wager that unemployment will not come even close to the unemployment levels under pre-COVID Trump, but rather, hover between 5.4% and 6.6%. https://fortune.com/2020/09/28/covid-buisnesses-shut-down-closed/

These are the same companies having supernova balance sheets. So the only mitigation of unemployment will come from the Federal Government. Even the resulting figures will be the unsustainable path of Federal quantitative easing.

January is 6.3pc. Trends since 2011 is falling except for huge leap for 2020.  However crunch time for coronavirus will hit during this year when relief efforts start to fade out and we start to try and return to something more normal.  As people go back to work unemployment will drop, as businesses fail due to running out of money and support it will go up.  The disruption will also instigate change.  So overall think it will hover between 6 and 7pc as the two effects net each other off.  More likely to creep up though as some people will have taken themselves out of the employment market for a while to cope and will have been using savings or if they didn’t need to work, and they may start to come back into the numbers
Given the way unemployment is calculated and summer vacation from online school it seems unlikely that we would see any drop in unemployment before September.

There will be new jobs and the number of employed will certainly go up, however, there is a very large pool of  potential worker who will begin returning to the labor market looking for work.  I do not see the economy absorbing them fast enough for the rate to fall under 7%.

Weighting my probabilities toward lower unemployment on vaccine distribution trajectory.  There is a built up demand for workers if people/companies start buying, and they WANT to, they just need to feel safe.
If COVID continues to decline I would expect gravitational pull back toward what it was pre-COVID, which was around 4%.

At first glance, the drop in the unemployment rate of 0.4 percentage point seems like good news. A rise or fall of just 0.1 percentage point in the rate translates roughly to 160,000 people, which is equivalent to the population of a medium-sized U.S. city, so that would suggest over 600,000 people were no longer unemployed. But the rate didn’t fall because more people, on net, found jobs. It fell because over 400,000 people “vanished” from the labor force – the vast majority of them women. The data show that yes, about 606,000 people were no longer considered unemployed in January, but only 201,000 people actually found jobs. This is because to be classified as unemployed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics a person must be without a job, currently available to work and actively looking for work in the previous four weeks. This excludes a lot of people who used to be gainfully employed but essentially got discouraged. In total, there were about 4.4 million fewer people in the labor force last month compared with a year earlier. That gives us a participation rate of 61.4% – the lowest it’s been since 1975, excluding the worst months during the pandemic.
https://theconversation.com/latest-jobs-report-shows-why-the-unemployment-rate-needs-fixing-154695 “Published unemployment rates during Covid have dramatically understated the deterioration in the labor market,” Powell said in remarks made earlier this month, noting that the unemployment rate that counts those who are not looking for work would be closer to 10%. Speaking at an event on Monday, Yellen said that 10 million Americans are officially counted as unemployed while another 4 million have dropped out of the labor force. Working mothers of young children have seen a particularly sharp drop in labor participation over the course of the pandemic, according to a recent report from the Minneapolis federal reserve.
https://www.theguardian.com/business/2021/feb/23/fed-chair-jerome-powell-economic-reovery As the economy picks up i am assuming the people actively seeking employment will rise too. Hence spreading out my estimate (Need to see how the participation rate move too)

Using previous recoveries and their respective U3 decline speeds as base rate:
Last 3 months - 4.9%
Last 4 months - 3.7%
2011 pace - 5.8% (chosen as recovery from financial crisis had started in earnest)
Apr 14 to Apr 15 pace - 5.8% (chosen as ongoing recovery and starting point of 6.2% is close to where we are now). I am not sure how you handicap each different recovery, so assuming there is a recovery I will assume two paths one that gets U3 down to below 5% and another that gets it down to around 5.8%, to which I will give equal probabilities in this initial forecast (with a bit of a spill over from 5.8% to 5.9% of 6% due to proximity). Will also assume a 16% chance that recovery is not smooth.
Unemployment Rate in the United States averaged 5.77 percent from 1948 until 2021, reaching an all time high of 14.80 percent in April of 2020 and a record low of 2.50 percent in May of 1953.

The Unemployment Rate will move relatively slowly towards lower unemployment. Looking at the past unemployment rates such as those after the GFC, show that it typically returns to "normal levels" gradually.  The stimulus package will have a slight affect of lowing unemployment rate, however, the abnormally high unemployment benefits may tempt people to stay unemployed.  Comparing to Australia's COVID stimulus package, which was approximately 1/5th of the budget and reduced unemployment by 1% over an 8 month period. The US is using a much larger portion of money, but given concerns of implementation and citizen reaction that has been raise, i suspect that the effects may be delayed. Overall, with the vaccine roll-out i expect the unemployment levels to gradually move to the levels before the crisis.

Obviously the lockdowns have had a tremendous effect on unemployment by forcing businesses to close. So as the lockdowns are lifted over the next few months it would seem reasonable that unemployment would fall.  However the economy had some major, major structural problems before the virus came along. We were going to have a recession even without the virus.  Inflation is now running above 3%, and as that becomes true on a year-over-year basis it's going to force interest rates on loans higher. Our economy is addicted to low interest rates, and higher interest rates and higher inflation will absolutely crash the economy. The everything bubble is popping in 2021. Just look at the last four or five months of CPI inflation, and look at how treasury yields have been rising. The economy can no longer handle normal interest rates. the government will respond by doing the only thing they can do which is create more money, which will cause more inflation.  There are also 5.2 million businesses out there that took PPP loans and kept their employees on staff so that they wouldn't have to repay those loans. So the government is essentially paying for the employee costs for those businesses, and the business can still claim the employee expense as a write-off. After 24 weeks however, the employer can let the employees go and still be forgiven for the loan. so we are likely to see some layoffs as a result of this come spring and summer as these businesses effectively have to start paying their own employee costs again. Also we can expect the government to continue with extended unemployment compensation, which incentivizes people to stay on unemployment. And at least a third of our restaurants and bars are not coming back.

I predict that the vaccine rollout will continue to hamper people from "returning to normal" by the end of August though I do see more people breaking outside their bubble this summer. While I think covid-19 will have reduced cases in the summer, I don't believe the country will return to "normal" in 2021. I think people are still concerned about the virus and the various strains. Vaccine efficacy has been shown to decrease with the South African variant.

For the past 3 months, unemployment has decreased at a rate of about 0.2% per month. In comparison, after the GFC, when unemployment rates were around where we are now, they decreased by 0.8-1.2% in 12 months, or about half the current speed (of course, the situations are very different).
With January at 6.3%, we would expect 4.9% in August if recovery continues the rate it's at now. Assuming a slower recovery similar to post-GFC, that puts us at 5.6%.
With vaccinations rapidly increasing, it seems like recovery might speed up as lockdowns are lifted. However, there is no chance of things going back to business as usual as businesses have shuttered, the potential of extra unemployment benefits possibly lasting until fall, and permanent changes to how work is conducted.

January 2021=6,3 Since COVID-19, min=6,3 (decrease every month since april 2020). Since october 2020, -0,6
There should be no policy measures that would again severely restrain the economy, thanks to the vaccines and the summer season.
In previous years (excluding 2020 because covid) there was no significant increase or decrease in the month of August. Crowd Forecast and @SE_Meyer (top25 forecaster) are 72% and 100% for 5,4-5,9

The unemployment rate is likely to continue to fall by summer as the effects of covid subside due to the vaccine rollout and more businesses (especially restaurants and travel related businesses) open. This is likely to be sped up by increased stimulus. However, there might be limit to the number of people going back to work immediately, as some have moved, or have adjusted to being out of work for the meantime. This could mean the rate could stay inflated for much mid to late 2021. Because the rate is right now at 6.3%, I see it falling, very likely below 5.9% by August, but probably not below 5.4%.

Personally, I don't see the economy coming back as quickly as most people do. The restaurant, hotel and travel industry are still a long way from resuming their normal trade. And the office building reckoning in the commercial real estate sector has not even begun. Many, many people are MONTHS behind on their rent.  And there will be spikes. My two cents.

Stimulus will help, but so will vaccines. But only about half of the population will have a jab by July which will impact the U3 rate. Shoppers will be cautious as will diners. Workers and employers may also be shy about returning.

6.3 currently. But there's a lot of considerations with the pandemic to take into account. The article I linked below gets into it. My understanding is the survey response rates are down due to the pandemic and so it may not be as accurate as normal, among other reasons. Jason Furman estimates in the linked article that the "realistic" unemployment, meaning his estimation of what the employment number would be if the pandemic wasn't screwing up the measurement, is 8.3%. But many of these lost jobs are also temporary and could come back very quickly once the economy opens more. His estimate of the "full recall unemployment rate" is 6.9%. The big question is whether the trend in U3 unemployment reported by the BLS continues and underlying issues with the measure remain the same, or whether these issues resolve and the number better reflects the "realistic" measure. Additionally, if the economy reopens it could reflect the "full recall" number. And of course, all of these numbers are likely to decrease over time. https://www.piie.com/blogs/realtime-economic-issues-watch/unemployment-continues-fall-workers-still-not-returning-labor My guess is that 6 months from now we'll be closer to the "full recall" number, and that with the pent up demand from stimulus packages and a majority of adults being vaccinated that number will have dropped a good amount. As an additional ballpark comparison, after the great recession the U3 unemployment reached 6.2% in April of 2014, and 6 months after that in October of 2014 it was 5.7%. I assume we'll have a faster recovery than that this time around. https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/UNRATE
